commentBody: We had bottomless brunch yesterday. But the opportunity to view the finalists for the Griddies, and to cast your vote, is not bottomless: it will close at end of day Friday. So grab your mimosa and head to the link below to read descriptions of the wordplay community‚Äôs favorite puzzles. Anyone can vote! https://form.jotform.com/250186385916162

16-Across is not correct: as per the current rules of Major League Baseball, any extra inning must commence with a runner pre-placed on second base. Therefore, a leadoff walk in such an inning would create TWO men on, not one. Please learn the MLB rule book . The clue should at least have said ‚Äòperhaps/maybe‚Äô etc.
Really enjoyed the circled letter trick

Crossword Revolution D9:  DEB AMLEN

Any revolution is better with Deb.  

This is a Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.  All rights reserved, including the right to be simultaneously up, down, lost, found, not to mention feeling the need to binge on TED LASSO.

This was quite a feat of construction.  Luckily HEARTTRANSPLANT and SOLDIEROFFORTUNE seemed obviously right to me, so I was able to guess that the missing letters must be in the circles.  Because 4 letters needed to be added to get the right answers, the up and down nature of the gimmick was the only way to make it work.  Seeing that I was off to the races.

My biggest problem came at 1D because, seeing To Be Young Gifted And Black in the clue immediately put me in mind of Nina Simone, and Simone fit nicely.  Too bad I didn‚Äôt  immediately notice that that clue said familiarly.  The crosses soon apprised me of error, and I replaced one soulful titan with another.

I couldn't figure out how it wanted the bottom circles entered, so it ruined my gold star. I thought it wanted ARTTRA in the bottom circle of 3D, for example. So I got all four of those bottom circles wrong, and wasted time looking to find if something else was wrong, and had to do a check puzzle in the end.

Frustrating.

My four year old: ‚Äúwhat are those circles? They look like ladders.‚Äù

He caught the Thursday trick before I did. 

Thanks, kiddo, gold star for you.
Very clever theme, great job, Joe!
This was fun! Always happy when I can figure it out.

Liked. 

This was an up, not a down. 

Thanks!
We love palindromes !! What goes up must come down üòÄ
Masterful work on this crossword. I enjoyed it a lot. Confused at first but figuring out what's going on is always part of the joy of the crossword. Well done!

I completed the puzzle, without a clue of what was supposed to happen in the circles until I came to the column.  The trick was cute.  I'm not crazy about cute, but this was a sort of tour de force of cuteness, so I conceded that Joe Marquez constructed a tour de force of a rebus puzzle.  Fair clues, solid fills, well done.

Thank you, Joe, my hat is off to you.

"What goes up must come down..." I'm glad this puzzle didn't take any Blood, Sweat &Tears: https://youtu.be/SFEewD4EVwU?si=E4B9_v9XaLhUdcjs I'm also glad I started in the SW, so the revealer gave me all I needed to know for when I made my way up to CAN'T SEE STRAIGHT. Overall, I found the fill quite gentle, but the theme entries made my heart jump up and down in joy. What an amazing idea for a puzzle, Mr. Marquez. Thank you!
Ballad of the green berets is my favorite SOLDIERTUNE

That was cool :) I caught onto the theme at HEARTTRANSPLANT, then specifically went to work on the rest since they were fun to solve in their own right. I had a little trouble in the North East because I was thinking FORhire before realizing it was FORTUNE.  Once I got past that it was smooth sailing. Very very impressive theme, and I don't think the rest of the puzzle suffered for it.

I knew it had to be HEART TRANSPLANT, and fortunately had the circled letters filled in, so noticed the trick. That made it relatively easy to follow the pattern for the other theme answers, and get those placed properly. Liked the revealer when I got to it (late).

Had a few issues along the way, but managed to get them fixed, eventually.

A fun solve, thank you, Joe.
I did the puzzle in a little over 22 minutes, then I had to wait for wordplay to see how I did it.
Always a good feeling to figure out the trick without reading the column.  Today was a good feeling!   Helped that the clues were fairly straightforward.   Fun Thursday puzzle!
This one was definitely not worth the time expended, any time at all.

I'm in the elevator business. It has its ups and downs.

(But it's on the level.)
Okay Boomers! Enjoyable, not sub-par, it surfaced smoothly without blowing my ballast tanks. And like Otis (Redding not Elisha), it lifted my spirits.

I enjoyed this one top to bottom. Really all just clever and good. 

Wasn‚Äôt too easy. Wasn‚Äôt too hard. Just tricky enough without being too tricky for its own good. And, in the end, left me thinking about the creativity and mastery in its conception and construction. Good times. 

My thanks to Joe Marquez.

Very nice Thursday puzzle. After a Mon - Weds that felt slightly more difficult than usual, this felt just right to me. Clever theme which wasn‚Äôt too hard to pick up on, and once I did, the theme actually helped the solve: an inner palindrome can almost be thought of as a third, implicit cross. Fun mechanics!
Wow, a truly amazing feat of construction! I am in awe.
As others mention, once I figured out HEARTTRANSPLANT the rest came easily. I did this in average time. Yet again I am impressed by the constructor‚Äôs conceit. This was a lark from start to finish.

Thursday puzzles are fun (in my view) when I can catch onto the trick without consulting the column. Today was fun. Any difficulties I experienced were of my own making.

Gone too soon is Andre Braugher, aka Captain Ray HOLT on Brooklyn Nine-Nine.  His stern demeanor and eloquent use of language elevated an otherwise silly show.  

So @Deb, are you a Dr. Who fan? I‚Äôm obsessed! The evolution of the series from the original series to today is entertaining to watch.  The newest Doctor, Ncuti Gatwa, has such a charming and exuberant personality! He shocked everyone, and some people are still angry at his selection (womp, womp!).

I hope it‚Äôs warm and dry wherever you are!

That was a neat trick but the puzzle seemed very easy to me, for a Thursday. I slept really badly last night and there is something not entirely pleasant on my mind, yet I managed to fill the grid in the morning in Tuesday time without any lookups.

Btw, I had to get ABE from crosses (and most of the other names, too) but HOLT was a gimme ü§£

I enjoyed this so much, my fastest Thursday ever! It helped that I figured out the trick fairly early on via HEART TRANSPLANT, and the rest just flowed.

Thanks Joe!

Strands Thread.  Pause any spoilers until after the View All Replies  button please:


Strands #333
‚ÄúStopping by woods on a snowy evening‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµ


Simple spanner.  The challenge was memory.
This was a perfect Thursday puzzle for me. All came together without any frustration, and I appreciated that the clues involved in the trick were get-able without being too easy. No notes!

I never comment, but I loved this puzzle as someone who's relatively new to crosswords. Gave me immense satisfaction once I figured out user research as someone who's in the research field myself üòÑ

That was fun, no matter how you look at it.

I caught on to half the trick when I saw FOR floating over SOLDIER and RES attached to SEARCH. So I confidently filled in ‚Äúhire‚Äù to complete the soldier entry and racked my brain to come up with a single letter to place in front of ‚Äúresearch‚Äù. (‚ÄúDo all the cool kids refer to market research as just M-research now?‚Äù) Eventually, I got the revealer, all the lightbulbs went off, and everything fell into place.

For me, a good Thursday-puzzle moment of realization is almost like a drug.  It hits quickly, gives you a rush, and leaves you wanting more.  Thanks, Joe, for feeding my addiction.

I found this pretty bewildering! I clicked on the circles and up came a square with a border, a rebus! and I kept trying to put extra letters into the them; concluded that I was doing it wrong but didn't know how. 
I struggled with quite a few clues and didn't get the meaning of the 'revealer', which I expect is me still not getting themes.

Some really unknowable to me clues. I did know ABE! I assumed lead off referred to dog walking. Obviously that didn't work! Cat food, PSA, NSA, 1040, ENE, OSHA, all actors were not known. 
I thought STAT meant 'immediately'?
Another day.

I had "transplant" for 23A, which fit even though it was only half right. I also had "Iams" instead of ALPO, and "eek" instead of RUN. This messed-up my entire NW corner. Thankfully I had ABE right, which helped me get the downs, and ENTRAP showed me the trick.

Getting the theme quickly really helped me solve the rest of the puzzle and even the revealer, and I was impressed with the entire construction. How do people think up these things?

Looking back, "eek" in a horror movie would be quite laughable. üòÜ

Firstly, brilliant puzzle.

Secondly, the cover photo today reminded me of last summer, when I saw my first ever submarine (it was indeed also yellow.) Unexpectedly. In action. From the outside.

Namely, I was scuba diving in Tenerife, near a marina. We were having a regular, peaceful dive, just hanging out with an octopus, when suddenly there was a weird noise. Mind you, we‚Äôre at ~30m under but I figured it was a ship, didn‚Äôt give it much thought, there was a cute octopus, okay? Imagine my utter shock when a submarine passed us by, so close that I could see its passengers waving at us. 
I right about drowned then and there, and it took me several days to get The Beatles out of my head.

Definitely not my day today. I could not see my way through this (for me) impenetrable puzzle. 
TRANSPLANT fitted 23A perfectly, so couldn‚Äôt work out the HEART bit til I read Deb‚Äôs column. It all became a SPECK clearer, but not much. I‚Äôm still unsure about 52A. I get it; CANT SEE STRAIGHT, but the up section gives us TSE. Where‚Äôs the other E? Am I over thinking this? 

I‚Äôm going to chalk this one up in the ‚Äòdid not finish‚Äô column. Again and as always wowed by the constructor‚Äôs skill. I‚Äôm clearly in the minority today, which is a good thing. It really is me, not you. 

On the upside, it‚Äôs not raining or blowing a hoolie. And I‚Äôve been to visit the soon to be mine Alpacas; Primrose, Willow, Calypso and Lacey. Beyond excited.

Second in a row where getting the theme aided my solve, 

very enjoyable, 2025 Griddies nominee??
What a satisfying fill!
Just the kind of puzzle I anticipate all week! Thank you!

That was quite a puzzle. Surprised to be able to say that I actually caught on to the trick fairly early with HEARTTRANSPLANT*, but still got stuck in more than a couple of places for a bit and did have to cheat a bit. Figuring out each of the theme answers was just a lot of fun. Oh, and yeah - I've seen Lun Lun and Yang Yang. *and... HEARTTRANSPLANT led me to another unusual puzzle: A Thursday from July 9, 2009 by Ashish Vengsarkar. That one was in the clues. The clue for HEARTTRANSPLANT was: "HATER?" And some other theme clues and answers: "TROT?" TORTREFORM "RIFTS?" FIRSTAMENDMENT "GATES?" STAGEADAPTATION Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/9/2009&g=21&d=A I'm done. ....
Hmmmm, I wonder if there were no circles how long it would have taken to figure out the trick. In other news, the FAT CATS are in the house. https://gocomics.com/mattwuerker/2025/01/24
i really enjoyed this thursday puzzle, the themed clues were very fun and satisfying to solve!

This was fun. I thought I'd skip over the long ones and the circles for a while, then I filled in trANSPLANT for 23A. Not correct, but enough to get me started on the theme. 

I also spent some time trying to figure out how to fit Nina Nimone into 1D--a nickname I wasn't aware of, perhaps, until ARETHA came to me.

Beat my Thursday average, fun trick. Thanks!

Driving my kids to middle school
every morning, I‚Äôd say things like- 

‚ÄúMiddle school is tough. 
Get through the day. Be kind. That‚Äôs it, you nailed it.‚Äù

Or borrow from the great Milne,

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre braver than you believe, stronger than you seem, and smarter than you think.‚Äù

One morning my eldest said, 

‚ÄúYeah Mom, you always say that, 
but it‚Äôs really not bad! 
And‚Ä¶I dunno‚Ä¶ 
but I think I‚Äôm *really* smart.‚Äù

Oh. Right.
Check yourself, CC.
Your kids are *not* CC circa 1981. 

Go figure.


Fun puzzle! Thank you Joe!
Great puzzle, except caresses solving to PATS does not seem right. I had PETS at first but that didn‚Äôt work with the crossing.

An amazing construction and satisfying fill. 
Thank you!

Like the vast majority, I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.  Cleverly crafted, a nice variety of clues, with a few difficult enough to require some thought and a couple that needed reverse engineering (I should watch more TV?). Very satisfying. Well done.

Loved this Thursday! A good mix of simpler clues and ones that required more thought. I think that the theme was difficult enough that I didn‚Äôt get it right away, but once I figured out the theme entry, it made sense straight away. 38 Across is what made it click as I knew the word USER had to be in there somewhere, but couldn‚Äôt see how it would fit using all the across. Loved it!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Debut answers aren‚Äôt automatically good, but two today are gold ‚Äì SOLDIER OF FORTUNE and CAN‚ÄôT SEE STRAIGHT.
‚Ä¢	Speaking of CAN‚ÄôT SEE STRAIGHT, that phrase nicely echoes the theme, because the theme answers don‚Äôt run straight across.
‚Ä¢	Lovely misdirecting original clue for THEFTS: [They might sound the alarm].
‚Ä¢	A host of schwa-enders: GIA, ARETHA, UTA, PANDA, OSHA, MESA, STRATA, and wannabes BETA(s) and CODA(s).
‚Ä¢	TIL why shaking aspen trees shake, after looking it up.  Their leaves, due to their shape, flutter in even the slightest breeze, giving the trees the appearance of shaking.  This led to their scientific name ‚Äútremuloides‚Äù.  Cool!

So, Joe, your creation brought lots of smiles to spark my day.  Thank you so much for making it!
Loved this puzzle. A friendly reminder that though life has downs, it also has ups. Happy Thursday, all.
Fair dues to the Queen of Soul but, here's the origin story for 1D: https://youtube.com/watch?v=_hdVFiANBTk Great puzzle and many thanks.

This was a fun puzzle but all the up and down left me with an earworm -- I haven't thought of the song is years and years!
Those magnificent men in their flying machines, 
they go up, Tiddley up, up. 
They go down, Tiddley down, down
Well, I came here for clues and must say, NOW I GET IT! I obviously need to do more of these CL because I was so confused. Thanks all!
Well I was fooled on this because I tried to fill the themers in as rebuses amd they were not! In retrospect I admire the simplicity of making it work

On my second round of Acrosses, I saw
             O
_OLDIER_UNE, and I was off to the races üòä!  Great puzzle!

Been an odd CW week so far‚Ä¶might we say UP AND DOWN? My Monday time was a couple minutes slower than my Tuesday time. My Wednesday time was just about at my Thursday average while today was a minute and change under my Wednesday average. Still,I enjoyed today‚Äôs puzzle despite how relatively easy I found it. Caught onto the theme with HEART TRANSPLANT, so that helped. Some clever clues: Base for a proposal for KNEE. Work on a sub for EAT. 

I will say, however, the government-related clues/fills make me cringe lately‚Ä¶FEDERAL GRANTS on Monday; OSHA today. As I often told my students, Context is everything.

Solved in 23% less time than average.  HEARTTRANSPLANT was the first answer to clue me to the theme.

[stepping up on my soapbox]
A lot of folks point out, as I do, the relative difficulty of the day's puzzle.  Some like to phrase that perception as a complaint ("too easy/hard for a [insert day of the week]".  I think despite the editors best efforts you will frequently have puzzles that fall out of range of a given day's average.  

Given the diversity of solvers. It is not surprising that folks relative solving difficulty is all over the place.  It is fun to see how one's solving difficulty stacks up against the rest of the solvers, but to complain about it seems like wasted effort.  It is the nature of the beast for it to be that way.  Even if the NYT suddenly has the resources to increase the number of puzzle testers to help gauge what day of the week a puzzle should fall, I would imagine the results would not be much different.  

Enjoy the puzzle one is given, and if it seems harder than average, know that it won't be long before an easier than average puzzle comes along.
At first I wanted Aretha to be Odetta but then Mr. Lincoln got me straightened out on this rebus free Thursday.
There are no sandwiches in Philadelphia called ‚Äúsubmarines.‚Äù
Isn't George Washington the first president born outside of the original 13 colonies?
Impressive!!!
today's experience was all up, no down... well except fictional prison guarded by dementors...  maybe i live under a rock, but a lot of references elude me.

Lovely Thursday puzzle! A very clever theme, which luckily I discerned right at the start with SOLDIERTUNE. Even guessed in advance what the revealer would be. This made the puzzle quite easy, and I finished in just over 15 minutes, almost achieving a Thursday best. 

Would have been more challenging without the circles, but perhaps that would have caused too much frustration. About to read the comments, to see how much frustration has already been expressed.

Partly because I put in PETS instead of PATS for "caresses", until the end of solving I had EGO GAP for 48-down, which may be an even more common "separation in some relationships" than AGE GAPs lol.

Impressive and fun.  Stellar Thursday puzzle again.

Sorry to double post but I neglected to give a shout out to Captain HOLT who, after he'd given up trying to be intellectual, had resorted to playing videos games, namely the NYT crossword app. 

"It plays a little song when you solve it as if you've just learned to potty".  Victory jingle plays:  "Yes, yes, play me my dunce's tune!"

RIP Andre Braugher, you gave us many laughs!
52 across is supposed to be ‚Äúcan‚Äôt see straight.‚Äù  However, there‚Äôs only one ‚Äúe‚Äù in the solution, not two.  Am I missing something?
Fun puzzle, challenging but not impossible. Solved in 47 min with no lookups. One of those situations where I got UPSANDDOWNS early on and had to suss out what that meant as I was solving.

Have gun, will travel, reads the card of a man,
A knight without armor in a war-torn land...

So yeah, 18A got me into the gimmick, although I flirted with SOLDIER FOR hire, as others have mentioned. Perfect Thursday fun.
A delightfully fun Thursday puzzle. Reminded me of the Upson Downs in Auntie Mame w Rosalind Russel...always makes me laugh. Thanks Joe!

Oh joy. Trade names, TV characters, sports jargon. Clues that don't seem to be in the same section of the thesaurus as the solutions. And another theme that needs some good crosses to crack into.
I managed to discern heart transplant through that mess, which gave me clue to the revealer, which gave me a toehold, but after a while I was still going to need so many lookups that I just put it out of my misery with Reveal Puzzle.

Clever, though, and I can see why people with the right knowledge base have enjoyed it.

Such a fun puzzle, with a nice difficulty mix, clever clues, and a theme that I hope makes more folks smile than grimace.

Thanks Joe, I loved it. I did, did I!
Fun and clever, much enjoyed after tackling some really crunchy Saturday's earlier this month!
Fun!

One of those puzzles that leaves me in awe at its construction. I just love the Pigeon, Hawke or Crowe clue. Not even the presence of both golf and baseball related answers (my kryptonite) made this any less enjoyable for me
Fun puzzle with a neat trick. Enough crosses that I didn't need lookups. A couple complaints though - taste is not style, and pats are not caresses
Perfectly cromulent Thursday! I will confess that yesterday's puzzle with the "Bottomless brunch" gimmick got my puzzle-doing mind all turned around. So Ohhhhh, today is Thursday. I CANTSEESTRAIGHT!!

That was really clever. I do these everyday (using the archive sometimes more than once a day) and this the first I've encountered the up and down motif. 

I confess, not being a TV watcher I had problems at the intersection of the two TV characters in the bottom right grid, but other than that smooth sailing.
Well done Joe! The amount of work that goes into a puzzle with a trick like this is phenomenal.
outstanding puzzle - the level of effort was incredible but still created a wickedly fun solve. bravo to the creator!!

The last couple days are starting to make me feel like I can do trickier puzzles. At first I thought it was a similar trick to yesterday because I knew it had to be heart transplant but it didn't fit. I tried HEARTTRANS, which fit and made me think the trick was that there would be a missing word at the end of each theme clue or some such. The crossers disabused me of that idea and I eventually got to the revealer, which opened up the rest. It was a nice aha moment when UPSANDDOWNS clicked and I realized the circles had to be significant. I'm sure more seasoned cruciverbalists saw it a lot sooner though, judging from the significant number of 'easy for a Thursday' comments.

NOTES: 
‚Ä¢ Sad to say I originally put STEVIE for 1D, which worked with EST and encouraged me to follow the trail to a dead end before remembering that it was an ARETHA album, which I have listened to many times (sigh).
 
‚Ä¢ I truly don't know if I could have completed the puzzle without 26D. It was almost the only longer clue that I knew for certain and it really helped anchor the entire center. I can understand why anyone unfamiliar with Harry Potter would have struggled that section. Although I think we are at a point where‚Äîwell-deserved authorial controversy notwithstanding‚ÄîHarry Potter trivia should likely be considered General Knowledge.

Peace!

I really appreciated the cleverness of the theme. A truly worthy Thursday!  

At the same time, a little on the easy side. Finished under 12 minutes with a hunt to find a typo.

I am not under any illusion that this comment adds to the discourse, but I‚Äôm proud to say that I figured out the theme almost right away, which is a new achievement unlocked for me on a Thursday puzzle!

This was fiendishly tricky; I dare say it‚Äôs even trickier than a rebus puzzle. I used to think I couldn‚Äôt solve Thursday puzzles without Autocheck, but after successfully tacking this unassisted, I think the training wheels are finally coming off! Look, ma, no hands!
My favorite thing!  Figuring out the gimmick halfway through and having it help me fill. Versus my usual MO of somehow finishing without getting the theme.
That was fun. Thanks!

I was pretty sure of HEART TRANSPLANT, but when it didn't fit I thought, jeez, I  CAN'T SEE STRAIGHT. But I eventually got the trick and used it on the other circled-letter answers - one of the few times in my fairly short crosswording career that the theme has actually helped with the solve. Lots of fun!

This was a really fun one! The difficulty felt just about right for a Thursday too.

Like @Jay, @David Hancock, and others, I managed to figure out the theme about 1/2 way through, which helped immensely. That doesn't happen very often, and I like to think it's a sign of both the puzzle's quality and my own improving skill.

This was lots of fun, and I was helped by seeing what was going on with the circles fairly early on. I just read a few comments and see that others had that experience too. 
It was still crunchy enough that I felt good about finishing it. There were a few proper names I didn‚Äôt know, but most were taken care of with crosses. 
Thanks for the challenge and the fun, Joe Marquez, and for the very entertaining column, Deb. Loved the Doctor Who clip ü§£

Well done! I certainly enjoyed today‚Äôs puzzle especially since it‚Äôs my birthday and essentially my new year! I ended up finishing it with the time being 1:38:03 and I turned 38 at exactly 8:27 hours and it‚Äôs the 1st month of the year too. Yes, I‚Äôm into numerology and it took me longer than usual to do loved ones contacting me lol! Life is certainly full of ups and downs though and I really liked how those 4 answers ended up being off by a letter but the grid and circled letters made it more interesting and fun! Thrilling Thursday and Namaste!!
I was really not enjoying the puzzle until about halfway through when I finally figured out the up/down construction. Completely changed my view and ended up really appreciating it!
I‚Äôm always so relieved when I don‚Äôt know the first name of a supermodel!

Yes, a fun one, once you fit heart transplant into 10 letters.  (I scoured my mind and the internet for something like "Heany Procedure" that's how blind I was to the nice pattern at first.)  

But I admit I was also stuck on the clouded mind, insisting that it had to be something about not seeing the trees for the forest (yes, I know that's backward).

But, a Python Script Mr. Marquez, seriously?  Now I don't feel so bad looking up *a few* things. If you can bring on the big guns, it's tit for tat...
So sorry this puzzle happened to hit just as we woke up to news of a terrible air tragedy in DC. I cannot deal with it today.

Fun puzzle with a clever theme.

A bit fast for me, but maybe I'm getting better.  (I just discovered the stats section, and this was 15 minutes below my Thursday average.)

Hopefully I don't improve so much that a puzzle like this takes ten minutes.
Solved much of this without the theme and had my "AHA" moment with HEARTTRANSPLANT. Good fill, great theme. Excellent puzzle!

Whenever I hear "ups and downs" I always think of 'Auntie Mame', where the parents of the girl who Patrick is going to marry, whose name is Upson, refers to their house as Upson Downs. (Luckily, the marriage never happens.)

Another Thursday, and another puzzle with grid entries that are not words.

I guess it‚Äôs clever, but it‚Äôs also not a crossword.

I'm late to the party, having a struggle today with deadlines to complete projects (I'll manage one, at least....) and then reading a lot about the "Fork in the Road" (worrying about who's about to get forked) and reading Joyce Vance (no relation), Robt Reich, Heather Cox Richardson...

I did the puzzles, but perhaps with less relish.  Niice little gimmick today, but not the usual Thursday challenge.

Back to the sewing machine.  All y'all hold on tight!

Since when is a USEARCH a [Focus of a product development test]?

(Thought I'd throw out some red meat for the elite solvers!)
Very fun! As opaque as this could have been, the clueing really helped with recognizing the trick.

Plugged away at this one til I can barely see straight! 
Actually, I‚Äôm proud of myself for figuring this out.

Thanks to this blog and community for all the help in the past and future!
What‚Äôs going on here. Since Will came back the puzzles are extra bad. Bring back Joel?

Late puzzle find - appropriate in the near future. A Thursday from February 2 (!) , 1995 by Bob and Sharon Klahn. That was a 15 x 15, but... there was one 16 letter answer straight down the middle of the puzzle, with the first letter jotting out from the top. And that answer? PUNXSUTAWNEYPHIL Just thought that was enormously clever. Oh - and some other answers in that one: GROUNDHOG WOODCHUCK and... SIXWEEK And the clue for SIXWEEK was... "Like a certain period of burrowed time?" Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/2/1995&g=1&d=D ..

I enjoyed the theme once i figured it out! (I was worried a head transplant was shortened to "headsplant" , but can't for the life of me put together "walks, for one" and "stat" what's the connection??
Gods, that was a good one!  All hail Thursdays.

Thank you, Joe Marquez. That was a delight overall. The theme was very crunchy.

I finished in 47 min with no help, against my average of 68 min.

Ha ha, SOLDIEROFFORTUNE reminded me of the time I bought a subscription to a magazine by that name as a birthday surprise for my husband (now my ex-). He was furious, saying I had ruined his security clearance for the rest of his life.

But I really came here to learn where I can find comprehensive country-based stats on innies and OUTTIEs, LOL.

Fun, through it took me a while to get the trick with the circled letters. When I did SOLDIERHIRE became SOLDIERTUNE, TRANSPLANT because HEANSPLANT and ASEARCH became USEARCH. I was stuck on CANTRAIGHT forever, it seemed. They sure do look hilarious when read that way though ü§£

I'm probably the only one annoyed that one of the tricky clues doesn't exactly match the formatting of the others and it tripped me up. The first two flow upwards and end as a completed word, "OF" and "USER", and then come back down to form another word, whereas "See" is cut off and has to use "E" twice, before starting Straight below it. Does that make any sense? Lol.

Am I the only sap who tried to put the six letters into a rebus (knowing that two (or four) of those letters were in the circles above.  Once i completed the puzzle without music, and searched exhaustively for errors, I finally it autocheck which told me my rebuses (rebi) were evidence that I CANTSEESTRAIGHT.  Oh well, I'm happy to have completed a Thursday with a reasonable time and no lookups.
That was fun!  Cute theme. Thanks!
I thought the theme was clever.
Always fun to get the gold on the last clue, especially considering it‚Äôs a Thursday.
A Thursday puzzle I could figure out on my own! Very clever and fun.

@Tim Shaindlin sure it‚Äôs correct.  The clue is ‚Äúresult of a lead off walk‚Äù.  So ‚Äúone on‚Äù is a potential result of a lead off walk.  Or a lead off hit‚Ä¶.or even a dropped 3rd strike.  I think there are 9 ways to reach first.

Ah. I was completely confused as to what ONEON meant. Of course, it‚Äôs a sporting reference (right or wrong). Thanks.
@Tim Shaindlin Please, the less mention of that absurd rule, the better.

@Helen Wright Let me break it down for you, going from simplest to most complicated. In baseball, ONE ON means one man on base. One of the three bases other than home has a runner on it. The term "leadoff" means the first batter up in an inning. Anytime the leadoff batter makes it on base in any way, that's a ONE ON situation for the next batter. A walk is a free pass to first base, earned by letting four pitches that are out of the strike zone go by without attempting to hit them. The strike zone is the imaginary area that is over home plate (home base) and covering a vertical area best described by the drawing here: https://businessinsider.com/mlb-strike-zone-2014-9 Thus, when a leadoff batter gets a walk, there's ONE ON. Any questions?

@Jack McCullough 

I had great trepidation when that rule went into effect, but I've come to realize that 18-inning games are no fun.  It's nice to sit down to watch a game at 7:10 and know that (barring rain delays), the game isn't going to go past 11:00.

The rule rewards teams with great closers.  Any closer that can strike out batters at will won't care much if there's a runner at second base.  

The designated hitter, on the other hand, is a blot on the sport.

This was a pleasure to do, and fairly quick; just what I needed while watching the horrible news from DC.

Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening By Robert Frost Whose woods these are I think I know. His house is in the village though; He will not see me stopping here To watch his woods fill up with snow. My little horse must think it queer To stop without a farmhouse near Between the woods and frozen lake The darkest evening of the year. He gives his harness bells a shake To ask if there is some mistake. The only other sound‚Äôs the sweep Of easy wind and downy flake. The woods are lovely, dark and deep, But I have promises to keep, And miles to go before I sleep, And miles to go before I sleep. Copyright Credit: Robert Frost, ‚ÄúStopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening‚Äù from The Poetry of Robert Frost, edited by Edward Connery Lathem. Copyright 1923, ¬© 1969 by Henry Holt and Company, Inc., renewed 1951, by Robert Frost. Reprinted with the permission of Henry Holt and Company, LLC. Source: Collected Poems, Prose, & Plays (Library of America, 1995) https://poetryfoundation.org/poems/42891/stopping-by-woods-on-a-snowy-evening

Scott,

This is a crossword puzzle. It is supposed to be tricky. Later in the week. there will be plenty of less common meanings or more remote connections in the answers. That most people would pick pets before pats is exactly why the clue was used today; on Monday, the clue might be [Pieces of butter].

Caress was a highlighted synonym for pat in the listing, and that makes it more than valid (if that is possible) for a crossword. If all clues and answers were most common usage, many of us would find puzzles no puzzle.

Cleo,

You read TSE "up and down" 
(as 57 Across tells you to do).

CAN TSE EST RAIGHT

(Reparse as CANT SEE STRAIGHT)

@Cleo 

(across) C-A-N-T (up) S-E (back down) E-S-T (across) R-A-I-G-H-T

It's just the double letter that makes it weird. Try it with one of the other clues and you'll see that you were doing the same thing.

@Byron I get what you're saying and I can't think of a really compelling argument. But those two examples seem to me very different in spirit somehow.

@Byron I'll try to explain I guess. Yesterday's clue felt to me that it had a very obvious direction with at least ten equally possible answers. Literally randomly choose a sports team from California. That's why I said it had no possibility of validating the solver's intelligence; there was no intelligence involved other than knowing some sports teams and then choosing one at random. It feels like the wrong kind of trivia, or at least a lazy kind. Who am I to say it's not perfectly valid? Agreed. There are no rules outside of established NYT Crossword norms and it is ipso facto perfectly valid. It just felt kinda bad. Today's clue at least had the chance of making the solver feel clever. I think RAKE is a great answer. And I bet it made you feel superior to the constructor, if slightly disappointed. I went with RAZE right away because I already had AZKABAN and it felt good to plug it in knowing that I had done some lateral thinking and gotten it right.

Anyway. I think everything to death so hopefully it doesn't feel like I'm bludgeoning you with this overcooked justificatory screed. I appreciate that you pushed back. You're probably right in all the ways that matter.
@Byron Something like "Angelic letters on Socal scoreboards" would have been more satisfying IMO.
@Scott. Another alternate clue, seemingly easier but probably harder:  ‚ÄúCalifornia baseball team whose scoreboard initials used to be ANA‚Äù
@Tom Exactly! Make it fun! Imagine if Jeopardy had a clue like "The two letter postal abbreviation for a Canadian province".

@Scott Jeopardy clues by nature have to have just one solution. This is not true for crosswords. Never was, never will be. Constructors do take pains to assure that there aren‚Äôt two solution sets, For example, for the [Caresses] clue, the answer can be either PATS or PETS, but the crossing answer can‚Äôt be similarly ambiguous. The cross must make it obvious which one goes this time. Unless, of course, it‚Äôs intentional. Like the greatest puzzle of all time, on Nov. 5, 1996, a presidential Election Day. https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/5/1996 This should end the discussion for sure.

@Steve L hmmm. I think I may have been misconstrued which is likely my fault. I'm certainly not saying the clue was invalid. The jeopardy example was just an illustration of why I thought the clue was unsatisfactory. Obviously jeopardy would never do that. I'm not trying to say why I think it was wrong; I'm trying to say why I think it was bad. Which is obviously a matter of personal opinion and can only be backed up with gut feelings, metaphors, and illustrations. I got the clue so obviously it didn't prevent me from finishing the puzzle. I'm not trying to suggest ways of making puzzles easier; just how to make them, from my perspective, better.
@Steve L And I'm not sure about being told something will end the discussion. Might just be me but I kinda like discussions.
